bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, January 30, 1943

div1.p: Kean is concerned that he has wrongly portrayed Gorgas as slow in supporting Reed's findings.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, January 30, 1943
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Jan. 30/43
My dear Col. Hench
div1.p:
Your good letter of the 25th gave
me great pleasure and relieved me
of some anxiety at having no
news of you since your letter of
Dec. 12. I had gotten up in the morn-
ing with the resolution to write a
note to Mrs. Hench to ask if you
had been ordered away on some
military errand, but the arrival of
your letter in the morning mail
made that unnecessary. Then I
intended to send you a line or two
at once to express my satisfaction.
But a meeting of the T.J. Memorial Com-
mission was called for that day
AC
K
2
to arrange the numerous details for the
dedication of the memorial on the 13th of April
which is the 200th anniversary of Jefferson's
birth and this took up more time than
I expected. They called on me for informa-
tion as to the number and addresses of
his living descendants which no one in
the world can give, but about which I have
probably as much information as any one.
But I have been occupied with a corres-
pondence that will interest you much more
than this. A day or two after the luncheon
on Dec. 15. Col. Hume came to see me
and asked if I have written out any
thing to say on that occasion. I told him
that I had some notes, but nothing
that would be of any value & gave him an
idea of what I had had in mind to say.
3
He said he would like much to have
it if I would write it out and I did so.
He had it typed and sent me several
carbons of it. One of these I am sending
to you and you may keep it with your file.
One I have sent to Col. Phalen saying that
he may want to have it on file in his
office, in case some of Gen. Gorgas's
friends may think that the first state-
ment in my citation trespasses somewhat
on ground sacred to Gorgas, and this
shows that it does not, quoting Gorgas
's own words. It also gives his defense
against the criticism of Reed's friends
that Gorgas was unduly slow in
supporting Reed's published conclusions.
As the names signed to the citation are
Capt. Mann's and Col. Phalen's as Pres. & Secy
4
of the Assn. Mil. Surgeons, they should
have this information on file.
NOW I want you also to see Hume's letter
to me in order that you may understand how
he as a Vice President of the Assn and as an
active promoter of the whole affair and one of
the speakers, feels about it. BUT I am
exceedingly anxious that the criticism
of Capt. Mann should not get out. So please
do not show this letter to anyone or
mention it. I as one of the honored
guests do not want to be a critic
of it. I already said more than I
should, in my letter to you of Dec. 20th
and I hope that you will not mention
that either. I would much regret
to have either Mr. Kellogg or Capt. Mann
know of this. Of course Hume was on
a different footing and as an officer
5.
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
of the Assn. Mil. Surg. is at liberty to
express an opinion, as I am not.
So will you please return Hume's letter
to me by return mail, as soon as you
have read it. Every one connected with
the whole affair has been wonderfully
kind and good to me. Among other
things they sent me several of the citations
beautifully engrossed and illuminated
and signed by the officials of the A.M. Sur-
geons. I want you to have one but will
send it to you at Rochester to be held
for you there. I want you to have it in
your collections of Y.F. manuscripts.
You said in your letter of Dec. 12 that you
would like to have some clippings about
the lunch. I think I sent you one in my
6
letter of Dec. 20 but am not sure. They
are now out of date but I have a great
bundle which Mr. Kellogg sent to Col
Hume and he has passed on to me. I will
put in two or three to show the wide
publicity which was given to this
occasion.

I feel sorry for Col. Hume as I do for you
that his post of duty is as little adapted
to his special gifts and liking as yours
are in your case. He ishas made a special
study of preventive medicine as applied
to armies, and as he knows half a dozen
languages and has acquaintances in the
medical staffs of half the countries in
Europe one would think his name
would be at the top for service in Europe
or Africa. Unfortunately he was not avail-
7.
able when we first sent over troops, as his wife
was in the last stage of a very painful disease
of the nervous system and he was very con-
siderately left on duty at the Field Medical
School at Carlisle Bks where she was in the post hospital, until her death last
Sept. His duty to his wife caused him to
lose the chances of foreign service up to
that time, and now he has to go to the
bleak plains of Kansas to organize a General
Hospital, which does not appeal to him
at all. Mrs Kean is calling me to lunch
so I must stop here and find an envelope
to take this letter plus the inclosures.
Just throw away the newspaper clippings
I have no use for these. I hope that you
have good reports from Mrs Hench and
will have no trouble in getting your leave
when her time comes. I think unless
AC
K
8.
the old regulations have been changed
your post commander can give you a week
or ten days leave which you could get
extended if necessary from Omaha.

Please give her my regards and good wishes
in which Mrs Kean joins me.
